Award.AwardTitle: Science Commissioning of the MMT's Ground-Layer Adaptive Optics System
Award.AbstractNarration: Adaptive Optics (AO) is a technique that allows astronomers to correct images received by a telescope for the distortions introduced as the light passes through the earth's atmosphere. The technique has made significant advances in recent years and its use is increasing and becoming routine at most of the world's largest telescopes. Now that AO is robust and reliable, scientists and engineers are seeking to apply it to a wider field of view so that larger objects or clusters of objects can all be viewed with the same high resolution at once. Dr. Michael Hart, of the University of Arizona, has been pursuing such a path for the MMT Observatory on Mount Hopkins in southern Arizona. This wide field will be realized by employing five ground-layer laser guide stars spread over a two arcminute field of view of the 6.5-meter telescope. By rapidly measuring the distortions of these guide stars over the field of view and correcting them with the MMT's adaptive secondary mirror, high spatial resolution over the entire field is being achieved. With the development effort nearly completed, Dr. Hart will now begin the last stage of the project to make the AO system fully robust and integrated with the instruments used by the scientists who have access to the 6.5-meter telescope. The new capability will make the observatory more efficient (less telescope time will be needed for objects of a given brightness) and allow for more detailed studies of structural details. This work is supported by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences program for Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With NSF support, both the 6.5 m MMT telescope and the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) have been equipped with advanced adaptive optics systems that sharpen images of astronomical objects by overcoming the blurring effect of the atmosphere. The adaptive optics rely on rapid measurements of the atmosphere obtained by shining laser beams into the sky along the telescope's line of sight. Pioneering work at the MMT led to the implementation of a system of five laser beams (Figure 1): from the signals, the image blur introduced by the "boundary layer" of atmosphere right in front of the telescope is estimated and corrected. This layer is particularly damaging to image quality, so removing its effect is of great value. Furthermore, because the boundary layer is so close to the telescope, the details of the image distortion depend little on the viewing direction. For that reason, if the boundary layer is corrected, image quality is substantially improved over a wide field of view.

The value of the multi-laser approach had been previously demonstrated at the MMT (Figure 2). Encouraged by that work, the LBT Observatory launched a program to implement a similar capability. The LBT system is called the Advanced Rayleigh Ground-layer adaptive Optics System (ARGOS); it uses three laser beams projected into the sky above each of the LBT's two eyes (Figure 3). Funding from this program has been used to transfer technical expertise from the MMT to ARGOS, and to support demonstrations of the new system's capabilities for science.

The science requirements for ARGOS led to two principal goals:

  • Enhance the near infrared (1-2.5 μm) image quality and ensquared energy by a factor of 2-3 for the telescope's LUCI imaging spectrograph instruments
  • Implement a reliable, low maintenance and robust system with high observing efficiency.

ARGOS now achieves those goals over the 4 arcminute field of view of the LUCI instruments with images that typically reach a resolution of 0.2-0.3 arcseconds. Figure 4 shows a composite image of galaxy NGC 6384 made by one of the two LUCI instruments. The blue and red channels of the image are made from observations in the J and H bands respectively. Around the natural guide star used for image motion correction (near the center of the field), image quality was measured to be 0.22 arcsec in H, and 0.34 arcsec in J. Tilt anisoplanatism at the edge of the field of view 2 arcminutes away reduces the overall image quality to about 0.35-0.4 arcsec, still a substantial improvement over natural seeing.

ARGOS commissioning continues, with updates to software in particular moving forward. But the system as a whole is now delivering the image quality for which it was designed.
